trivia: Hagia Sophia has served as a church, mosque, and museum throughout history.
The Bosphorus Bridge connects Europe and Asia, making Istanbul a transcontinental city.

clues: Home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World located in Egypt.
A bustling city on the banks of the Nile River with a rich history.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years.
Cairo’s Khan El Khalili market has been a major trading hub since the 14th century.
trivia: The Egyptian Museum in Cairo holds over 120,000 artifacts.
Cairo’s Al-Azhar University is one of the oldest universities in the world, founded in 970 AD.

clues: Known as the 'Red City' due to its distinctive colored buildings.
It is a gateway to the Atlas Mountains, which offer opportunities for hiking, trekking, and exploring Berber villages.
fun_fact: The Jemaa el-Fnaa square in Marrakesh has been a center of trade and entertainment for centuries.
Marrakesh was once the capital of Morocco and gave the country its name.
trivia: The Bahia Palace in Marrakesh was built in the 19th century as a grand residence for a former grand vizier.
Traditional Moroccan mint tea is a staple drink in Marrakesh’s cafés and homes.

clues: The largest city in Morocco, known for its modern architecture and coastal location.
Home to the Hassan II Mosque, one of the tallest religious structures in the world.
fun_fact: Despite its fame, the movie 'Casablanca' was not filmed in the city.
The city is Morocco’s economic and business hub, with a thriving port.
trivia: Casablanca’s Corniche is a popular promenade along the Atlantic coast.
The city’s French colonial architecture blends with traditional Moroccan influences.

clues: The capital of Kenya, known for its national park located within the city limits.
A major hub for wildlife conservation and safaris in Kenya.
fun_fact: Nairobi National Park is the only national park in the world located within a capital city.
The city’s name comes from the Maasai phrase 'Enkare Nairobi,' meaning 'cool water.'
trivia: Karen Blixen, author of 'Out of Africa,' lived in Nairobi, and her home is now a museum.
Nairobi is home to the world-famous Giraffe Centre, where visitors can interact with endangered Rothschild’s giraffes.

clues: A city famous for its stunning Table Mountain and scenic coastline.
Known for Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has more plant species than the entire United Kingdom.
Cape Town was the first European settlement in South Africa, founded in 1652.
trivia: The Cape of Good Hope was once believed to be the meeting point of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
The colorful houses of Bo-Kaap in Cape Town were originally homes of freed slaves.

clues: The largest city in South Africa, known as the 'City of Gold.'
Home to Soweto, a historic township tied to the anti-apartheid movement.
fun_fact: Johannesburg was founded in 1886 following the discovery of gold.
The city has one of the world’s largest urban forests, with over 10 million trees.
trivia: Mandela House, where Nelson Mandela once lived, is now a museum in Soweto.
Johannesburg’s OR Tambo International Airport is Africa’s busiest airport.

clues: The capital of Ethiopia, home to the African Union headquarters.
A high-altitude city known for its coffee culture and rich history in Ethiopia.
fun_fact: Addis Ababa is one of the highest capital cities in the world, sitting at 2,355 meters above sea level.
The city is home to Lucy, one of the oldest known human fossils, housed in the National Museum of Ethiopia.
trivia: Ethiopia is the birthplace of coffee, and Addis Ababa has a vibrant coffee culture.
The name Addis Ababa means 'New Flower' in Amharic.

clues: A coastal city known for its vibrant music and arts scene in Senegal.
Home to the famous Gorée Island, a historical site linked to the transatlantic slave trade.
fun_fact: The Dakar Rally, a famous off-road race, was originally named after this city.
Senegal’s capital is one of the westernmost cities in Africa.
trivia: The African Renaissance Monument in Dakar is taller than the Statue of Liberty.
Dakar’s Pink Lake (Lac Rose) gets its unique color from salt-loving algae.

clues: The largest city in Africa by population.
A financial and cultural hub with a thriving music and film industry in Nigeria.
fun_fact: Lagos was the capital of Nigeria until 1991 when it was moved to Abuja.
The city is known for its Nollywood film industry, producing thousands of movies annually.
trivia: Lagos has some of the busiest ports in Africa.
The city’s Lekki Conservation Centre has one of the longest canopy walkways in Africa.

clues: The capital of Tunisia, known for its medina and ancient ruins.
Located near the ruins of Carthage, a major civilization of antiquity.
fun_fact: Tunis' medina is a UNESCO World Heritage Site with centuries-old markets.
The city played a key role in the Arab Spring uprisings of 2011.
trivia: The Bardo Museum in Tunis houses one of the world's richest collections of Roman mosaics.
Couscous is Tunisia’s national dish and a staple in Tunisian cuisine.

clues: Home to a world-famous opera house with a sail-like design.
This city features one of the most iconic harbors in the world.
fun_fact: Sydney Harbour Bridge is also known as the 'Coathanger' due to its shape.
Bondi Beach is one of the most visited beaches in the world.
trivia: The Sydney Opera House hosts over 1,500 performances each year.
Sydney was the site of the first European colony in Australia, established in 1788.

clues: It is known as Australia's unofficial sporting capital. It's the only city in the world with five international standard sporting facilities.
This city hosts the Australian Open, one of tennis' Grand Slam events.
fun_fact: Melbourne has been ranked as one of the world's most livable cities multiple times.
The city has the largest tram network in the world.
trivia: Flinders Street Station is the busiest train station in the Southern Hemisphere.
The famous 'laneway culture' of Melbourne is home to many hidden cafes and bars.

clues: Capital of Queensland, known for its river and warm climate.
This city is the gateway to the Great Barrier Reef.
fun_fact: Brisbane is home to the world's first koala sanctuary, Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary.
The Brisbane River snakes through the city, giving it the nickname 'River City.'
trivia: The annual Brisbane Festival ends with the famous Riverfire fireworks display.
South Bank Parklands is a popular leisure area with an artificial beach.

clues: One of the most isolated major cities in the world, located in Australia.
Known for its beautiful beaches and proximity to Rottnest Island.
fun_fact: Perth is closer to Jakarta than to Sydney.
Rottnest Island is home to the friendly quokka, often called 'the world's happiest animal.'
trivia: Perth has more sunny days per year than any other Australian capital city.
Kings Park in Perth is one of the largest inner-city parks in the world.

clues: The largest city in New Zealand, known as the 'City of Sails.'
This city is built on a volcanic field with over 50 dormant volcanoes.
fun_fact: Auckland has more boats per capita than any other city in the world.
The Sky Tower is the tallest freestanding structure in the Southern Hemisphere.
trivia: Auckland was originally the capital of New Zealand before it moved to Wellington.
The city is home to a diverse population, with over 40% of residents born overseas.

clues: The capital city of New Zealand, known for its windiness.
This city is home to the national museum, Te Papa.
fun_fact: Wellington is the southernmost capital city in the world.
The city’s famous cable car offers stunning views of the harbor.
trivia: Wellington is often called 'Wellywood' due to its thriving film industry.
The Beehive is the nickname for the uniquely shaped New Zealand Parliament building.

clues: The capital city of Fiji, located on the island of Viti Levu.
It is often referred to as the 'New York of the South Pacific'.
fun_fact: Suva is one of the most multicultural cities in the Pacific.
The city is known for its vibrant markets and kava ceremonies.
trivia: Fiji gained independence from Britain in 1970, with Suva remaining its capital.
The University of the South Pacific, based in Suva, serves multiple Pacific island nations.

clues: The capital and largest city of Saudi Arabia, known for its futuristic skyline.
Home to the Kingdom Centre, a tower with a distinctive sky bridge.
fun_fact: Riyadh was once a small desert village before becoming the nation’s political and financial center.
The city experiences some of the hottest summers in the world, with temperatures often exceeding 45°C (113°F).
trivia: The name 'Riyadh' comes from the Arabic word for 'gardens,' referring to the area’s historical oasis.
The National Museum of Saudi Arabia in Riyadh showcases the country's rich history and culture.

clues: A major port city on the Red Sea and the gateway to Mecca.
Famous for the world’s tallest fountain, shooting water over 300 meters high.
fun_fact: Jeddah's Corniche stretches for miles along the coast, offering beautiful sea views and public art displays.
The city is known for its historic Al-Balad district, featuring centuries-old coral stone buildings.
trivia: Jeddah is home to one of the world’s tallest flagpoles, standing at 171 meters.
The city’s name means 'grandmother' in Arabic, referring to the legendary tomb of Eve, which is believed to be in Jeddah.

clues: The capital of Jordan, built on seven hills and blending ancient ruins with modern life.
Home to a well-preserved Roman amphitheater at the heart of the city in Jordan.
fun_fact: Amman has been continuously inhabited for over 7,000 years, making it one of the oldest cities in the world.
The Citadel of Amman offers panoramic views of the city and contains ruins from Roman, Byzantine, and Umayyad periods.
trivia: Jordan’s national dish, Mansaf, is widely enjoyed in Amman, made of lamb, rice, and fermented yogurt.
The city’s Rainbow Street is a vibrant cultural hub, known for its cafes, art galleries, and street performances.

clues: The capital of Lebanon, known for its rich history and Mediterranean coastline.
Nicknamed the 'Paris of the Middle East' due to its vibrant culture and nightlife.
fun_fact: Beirut has been destroyed and rebuilt seven times throughout history due to wars and natural disasters.
The city’s Pigeon Rocks are a famous natural landmark, attracting tourists and locals alike.
trivia: Beirut is home to one of the world’s oldest universities, the American University of Beirut, founded in 1866.
Lebanon has no official census data due to its diverse religious and ethnic communities.

clues: The capital of Iran, situated at the foot of the Alborz Mountains.
Home to the iconic Azadi Tower, a symbol of the city.
fun_fact: Tehran experiences both hot summers and cold, snowy winters due to its elevation.
The city has one of the busiest metro systems in the Middle East, carrying millions of passengers daily.
trivia: The Golestan Palace in Tehran is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and showcases Persian art and architecture.
Tehran’s Grand Bazaar is one of the largest and busiest markets in the world, spanning over 10 km of alleys.

clues: The capital of Oman, known for its stunning coastal scenery and traditional architecture.
Home to the Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque, one of the most beautiful mosques in the world.
fun_fact: Muscat has strict building regulations, ensuring the city retains its traditional Arabian charm.
The city is famous for its Mutrah Souq, a historic marketplace filled with Omani crafts and spices.
trivia: Muscat means 'anchorage' or 'safe harbor,' reflecting its history as a major trading port.
The Royal Opera House in Muscat is one of the most renowned cultural venues in the region.

clues: The capital of a country known for its 'Pura Vida' lifestyle.
Home to the National Theatre and a gateway to lush rainforests in Costa Rica.
fun_fact: San José was one of the first cities in the world to be lit by electricity in 1884.
The city is home to many gold and jade artifacts from pre-Columbian times.
trivia: San José’s Mercado Central is one of the oldest markets in the country.
The city’s name means 'Saint Joseph' in Spanish.

clues: A city famous for a man-made canal that connects two oceans.
Home to a modern skyline and the historic Casco Viejo district.
fun_fact: The Panama Canal generates about one-third of Panama’s GDP.
Panama City is the only capital city in the world that has a rainforest within its city limits.
trivia: Panama City was founded in 1519 and was the first European settlement on the Pacific coast of the Americas.
The ruins of the original city, Panamá Viejo, are a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: The birthplace of reggae music and home to the Bob Marley Museum.
The capital city of a Caribbean island famous for its beaches and Blue Mountain coffee.
fun_fact: Kingston has the seventh-largest natural harbor in the world.
Jamaica’s national dish, ackee and saltfish, is a staple in Kingston.
trivia: The University of the West Indies, founded in Kingston, is one of the most prestigious universities in the Caribbean.
The city is home to the National Gallery of Jamaica, showcasing local and Caribbean art.

clues: The oldest continuously inhabited European settlement in the Americas.
A city known for its Zona Colonial and the first cathedral built in the New World.
fun_fact: Santo Domingo was the first seat of Spanish colonial rule in the Americas.
The city’s Malecón is a famous seaside boulevard with vibrant nightlife.
trivia: Santo Domingo is home to the first university in the Americas, the Universidad Autónoma de Santo Domingo, founded in 1538.
Christopher Columbus’ remains were once housed in the city’s Columbus Lighthouse monument.

clues: The northernmost capital city in the world.
Famous for its colorful houses, geothermal pools, and the Hallgrímskirkja church.
fun_fact: Reykjavík translates to 'Smoky Bay' due to the steam from hot springs.
Iceland has no army, and its police officers do not carry firearms.
trivia: The city hosts the famous Iceland Airwaves music festival every year.
Per capita, Reykjavík has one of the highest rates of book consumption in the world.

clues: A Baltic capital with a well-preserved medieval Old Town.
Known for its digital society and being one of the world's most tech-savvy cities.
fun_fact: Tallinn was one of the first cities in the world to offer free public transport for residents.
Skype was originally developed in Estonia.
trivia: Tallinn’s Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The city was once known as Reval during the Middle Ages.

clues: The capital of a Baltic nation known for its baroque architecture.
Features a self-declared independent republic within its Old Town.
fun_fact: Vilnius is home to the Republic of Užupis, an artistic community with its own constitution.
The city is one of the greenest capitals in Europe, with nearly half its territory covered in greenery.
trivia: Vilnius’ Old Town is one of the largest and best-preserved in Europe.
The city’s name is derived from the Vilnia River.

clues: One of the smallest capital cities in the European Union.
Built by the Knights of St. John and known for its historic fortifications.
fun_fact: Valletta was built in just 15 years after the Great Siege of Malta in 1565.
It has over 300 monuments in just 0.61 square kilometers, making it one of the most concentrated historic areas in the world.
trivia: The city was named after Grand Master Jean Parisot de la Valette.
Malta was once a British colony, and English remains one of its official languages.

clues: One of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world in Armenia.
Famous for Mount Ararat views and pink-hued stone buildings.
fun_fact: Yerevan is older than Rome, founded in 782 BC.
Known as the 'Pink City' due to the color of its volcanic stone buildings.
trivia: The city’s Republic Square is considered one of the most beautiful squares in the world.
Yerevan is home to the Matenadaran, one of the world's richest depositories of ancient manuscripts.

clues: A capital city with a unique blend of European and Asian influences in Georgia.
Famous for its sulfur baths and scenic Old Town.
fun_fact: The name Tbilisi comes from the Georgian word for 'warm,' referring to its hot springs.
Tbilisi’s historic district has a mix of Art Nouveau, Persian, and Soviet-era architecture.
trivia: Tbilisi is known for its diverse cuisine, especially khinkali (dumplings) and khachapuri (cheese-filled bread).
The city is located on the ancient Silk Road.

clues: The coldest capital city in the world.
A gateway to the vast Mongolian steppes and nomadic culture.
fun_fact: Ulaanbaatar means 'Red Hero,' named after Mongolia’s independence movement.
The city is home to the world’s largest equestrian statue of Genghis Khan.
trivia: Nearly half of Mongolia’s population lives in Ulaanbaatar.
The city has some of the worst air pollution in the world during winter due to coal burning.

clues: The lowest capital city in the world, located below sea level.
Famous for its Flame Towers and oil-rich economy.
fun_fact: Baku is sometimes called the 'City of Winds' due to strong breezes from the Caspian Sea.
The world’s first oil well was drilled in Baku in 1846.
trivia: The Old City of Baku is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Baku hosts the annual Formula 1 Azerbaijan Grand Prix.

clues: The capital city of a country known for Victoria Falls.
A rapidly growing urban center in southern Africa.
fun_fact: Lusaka was a small village before becoming the capital in 1935.
The city is a key hub for Zambia’s copper exports.
trivia: Lusaka’s Freedom Statue commemorates Zambia’s independence from British rule.
The city has one of the largest open-air markets in Africa, the Soweto Market.

clues: The capital of a country known for the Namib Desert and stunning landscapes.
Nearly every Namibian national enterprise, governmental body, educational and cultural institution is headquartered in Windhoek.
fun_fact: Windhoek means 'Windy Corner' in Afrikaans.
The city is home to the famous Christuskirche, a landmark from the German colonial era.
trivia: Windhoek’s beer, Windhoek Lager, is brewed according to German purity laws.
The city is one of the cleanest capitals in Africa.

clues: Known as the 'Las Vegas of Asia' due to its booming casino industry.
It is the only place in China where casino gambling is legal.
fun_fact: Macau generates more gambling revenue than Las Vegas!
The Historic Centre of Macau is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
trivia: Macau has its own currency, the Macanese pataca, but Hong Kong dollars are widely accepted.
Macau is one of the most densely populated regions in the world.

clues: Famous for its lavish casinos, luxury yachts, and Formula 1 racing.
A playground for the rich and famous along the French Riviera.
fun_fact: The Monte Carlo Casino inspired the setting for the James Bond film 'Casino Royale'.
Despite being known for its casinos, locals are actually banned from gambling in them.
trivia: Monte Carlo hosts the Monaco Grand Prix, one of the most prestigious Formula 1 races.
Monaco has no income tax, making it a tax haven for many wealthy individuals.

clues: The northernmost capital of the world.
A small city surrounded by icy fjords and towering mountains in Greenland.
fun_fact: Nuuk is home to fewer than 20,000 people but is Greenland’s largest city.
The city’s name means 'cape' in Greenlandic.
trivia: Greenland is technically part of Denmark but has its own government.
Nuuk has no road connections to other Greenlandic cities; all travel is by boat or plane.

clues: The capital of an island nation famous for its stunning beaches and giant tortoises.
One of the smallest capitals in the world, located on an archipelago in the Indian Ocean.
fun_fact: Seychelles is home to the Aldabra giant tortoise, one of the longest-living species on Earth.
Victoria’s Clock Tower is a replica of London’s Vauxhall Clock Tower.
trivia: Seychelles was once a pirate hideout, and some believe hidden treasure still exists on the islands.
The country has the highest GDP per capita in Africa.

clues: A multicultural city on an island known for its sugar plantations and beaches in Mauritius.
Once a key stopover for trade ships sailing between Europe, Africa, and Asia.
fun_fact: Mauritius was the only home of the now-extinct dodo bird.
Port Louis has a vibrant street food scene influenced by Indian, Chinese, and French cuisines.
trivia: The island nation of Mauritius has no standing army.
Mauritius was the first African country to launch its own satellite.

clues: The capital of the world’s fourth-largest island, famous for its unique biodiversity.
Its name is often shortened to 'Tana' by locals.
fun_fact: Madagascar is home to more than 70 species of lemurs, found nowhere else on Earth.
Rice is a staple food in Madagascar, and the capital is surrounded by rice paddies.
trivia: Madagascar was once a French colony, and French is still widely spoken.
The island split from Africa around 88 million years ago, leading to its unique wildlife.

clues: The largest city in the biggest U.S. state, known for its cold climate and stunning landscapes.
Despite its massive size, this city in the USA has a small population and is surrounded by wilderness.
fun_fact: Anchorage has nearly 20 hours of daylight in the summer and only about 5 hours in winter!
Moose are common in the city, sometimes wandering into backyards.
trivia: Alaska was purchased from Russia in 1867 for just $7.2 million.
Anchorage is home to the Iditarod, a famous long-distance sled dog race.
